questions.question: Which layer of the OSI model is responsible for logical addressing and routing?
questions.explanation: The Network layer (Layer 3) handles logical addressing (IP addresses) and routing packets between networks. The Data Link layer handles physical addressing (MAC). The Transport layer manages end-to-end communication.

questions.question: Which OSI layer is responsible for establishing, managing, and terminating sessions between applications?
questions.explanation: The Session layer (Layer 5) manages sessions (dialogs) between applications, including establishment, maintenance, and teardown. The Presentation layer handles data formatting, and the Transport layer handles end-to-end delivery.

questions.question: A network engineer is troubleshooting and discovers a CRC error on received frames. At which OSI layer does this issue occur?
questions.explanation: CRC (Cyclic Redundancy Check) is a frame check sequence computed at the Data Link layer (Layer 2). CRC errors indicate corrupted frames, which are detected by the receiving NIC at Layer 2.

questions.question: What is the default subnet mask for a Class B IPv4 address?
questions.explanation: Class B addresses (128.0.0.0 to 191.255.255.255) have a default subnet mask of 255.255.0.0 (/16). Class A uses 255.0.0.0 (/8) and Class C uses 255.255.255.0 (/24).

questions.question: How many usable host addresses are available in a /26 IPv4 subnet?
questions.explanation: A /26 subnet has 6 host bits, giving 2^6 = 64 total addresses. Subtract 2 for the network and broadcast addresses, leaving 62 usable host addresses.

questions.question: Which transport layer protocol provides reliable, connection-oriented delivery?
questions.explanation: TCP (Transmission Control Protocol) provides reliable, ordered, connection-oriented delivery using a three-way handshake, sequencing, and acknowledgments. UDP is connectionless and unreliable. ICMP and ARP operate at other layers.

questions.question: Which TCP flag is used to initiate a connection during the three-way handshake?
questions.explanation: The TCP three-way handshake begins with the client sending a SYN (synchronize) flag. The server responds with SYN-ACK, and the client completes with ACK. FIN terminates connections; RST resets them.

questions.question: What type of cable is used to connect two similar devices (e.g., switch to switch) in older Ethernet networks?
questions.explanation: Crossover cables swap the transmit and receive pairs, allowing like devices to communicate. Straight-through cables connect unlike devices (PC to switch). Modern devices with Auto-MDIX can detect and adjust automatically.

questions.question: Which type of fiber optic cable is best suited for long-distance runs exceeding 2 kilometers?
questions.explanation: Single-mode fiber (SMF) uses a smaller core (8-10 microns) and a single light path, enabling distances of up to 100 km or more. Multimode fiber (MMF) typically supports distances up to 550 meters (OM3/OM4) at 10 Gbps.

questions.question: In the TCP/IP model, which layer corresponds to the OSI model's Data Link and Physical layers combined?
questions.explanation: The TCP/IP model's Network Access (Link) layer maps to both the Data Link (Layer 2) and Physical (Layer 1) layers of the OSI model. The Internet layer maps to Network (Layer 3), and Transport maps to Transport (Layer 4).

questions.question: Which wireless standard operates exclusively in the 5 GHz frequency band and supports speeds up to 1.3 Gbps?
questions.explanation: 802.11ac (Wi-Fi 5) operates exclusively in the 5 GHz band and supports up to 1.3 Gbps (Wave 1) or 6.9 Gbps (Wave 2). 802.11n and 802.11ax support both 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz. 802.11g operates only at 2.4 GHz.

questions.question: Given the IP address 172.16.45.200/21, what is the network address?
questions.explanation: A /21 mask is 255.255.248.0. The third octet (45) in binary is 00101101. ANDing with 11111000 gives 00101000 = 40. So the network address is 172.16.40.0.

questions.question: Which topology connects every device directly to every other device in the network?
questions.explanation: In a full mesh topology, every device has a direct link to every other device, providing maximum redundancy. The number of links for n devices is n(n-1)/2. Star uses a central hub/switch; bus uses a shared backbone.

questions.question: Which technology allows multiple virtual machines to run on a single physical server by abstracting the hardware?
questions.explanation: A hypervisor (Type 1 or Type 2) abstracts physical hardware and allows multiple virtual machines to run on one server. VLANs segment networks; containers share the host OS kernel; load balancers distribute traffic.

questions.question: What is the key difference between a Type 1 and a Type 2 hypervisor?
options: Type 1 runs on a host OS; Type 2 runs on bare metal
Type 1 runs on bare metal; Type 2 runs on a host OS
Type 1 supports only Linux; Type 2 supports only Windows
Type 1 is software-based; Type 2 is hardware-based
questions.explanation: A Type 1 (bare-metal) hypervisor runs directly on hardware (e.g., VMware ESXi, Hyper-V). A Type 2 (hosted) hypervisor runs on top of an existing OS (e.g., VMware Workstation, VirtualBox).

questions.question: An organization needs to create 14 subnets from the 10.1.0.0/16 network. What is the most efficient VLSM prefix length?
questions.explanation: To create at least 14 subnets, you need at least 4 borrowed bits (2^4 = 16 subnets). Starting from /16, borrowing 4 bits gives /20. /19 borrows 3 bits (8 subnets, insufficient). /21 borrows 5 bits (32 subnets, more than needed).

questions.question: Which IPv6 address type is equivalent to an IPv4 private address?
questions.explanation: IPv6 unique local addresses (FC00::/7, practically FD00::/8) are similar to IPv4 private addresses (RFC 1918). They are routable within an organization but not on the public internet. Link-local addresses are confined to a single link.

questions.question: How many bits make up an IPv6 address?
questions.explanation: IPv6 addresses are 128 bits long, written as eight groups of four hexadecimal digits (e.g., 2001:0db8:85a3::8a2e:0370:7334). IPv4 addresses are 32 bits.

questions.question: Which well-known port number does DNS use by default?
questions.explanation: DNS uses port 53 for both TCP and UDP. Port 25 is SMTP, port 80 is HTTP, and port 443 is HTTPS.

questions.question: What is the maximum recommended length for a Cat6a UTP cable run in a standard Ethernet network?
questions.explanation: The maximum cable length for Cat6a UTP in standard Ethernet (including 10GBASE-T) is 100 meters (328 feet). This includes the horizontal run, patch cables, and equipment cords.

questions.question: What is the broadcast address of the subnet 192.168.10.64/27?
questions.explanation: A /27 subnet has a block size of 32 (2^5). The subnet 192.168.10.64 has its next subnet at 192.168.10.96, so the broadcast address is 192.168.10.95 (one less than the next subnet).

questions.question: Which device operates at Layer 2 of the OSI model and uses MAC addresses to forward frames?
questions.explanation: A switch operates at Layer 2 (Data Link) and uses MAC address tables to forward frames to the correct port. Routers operate at Layer 3. Hubs operate at Layer 1 and flood all traffic to all ports.

questions.question: Which characteristic best differentiates containers from virtual machines?
options: Containers include a full guest operating system
Containers share the host OS kernel and are more lightweight
Containers provide stronger isolation than VMs
questions.explanation: Containers share the host operating system kernel and package only the application and its dependencies, making them much lighter than VMs. VMs include a full guest OS and run on a hypervisor. VMs generally provide stronger isolation.

questions.question: Which IPv4 address range is reserved for Automatic Private IP Addressing (APIPA)?
questions.explanation: APIPA uses the 169.254.0.0/16 range. When a device fails to obtain an address via DHCP, it self-assigns an address from this range. The other options are RFC 1918 private address ranges.

questions.question: Which protocol is used to resolve an IP address to a MAC address on a local network?
questions.explanation: ARP (Address Resolution Protocol) maps a known IPv4 address to a MAC address on the local network by sending a broadcast request. DNS resolves hostnames to IP addresses. RARP maps MAC to IP (legacy). DHCP assigns IP addresses dynamically.

questions.question: Which PDU (Protocol Data Unit) is used at Layer 4 of the OSI model for TCP traffic?
questions.explanation: At the Transport layer (Layer 4), TCP uses segments as its PDU. UDP uses datagrams. Layer 3 uses packets, Layer 2 uses frames, and Layer 1 uses bits.

questions.question: What is the frequency band and maximum theoretical speed of 802.11ax (Wi-Fi 6)?
options: 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz, up to 9.6 Gbps
questions.explanation: 802.11ax (Wi-Fi 6) operates on both 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz bands with a maximum theoretical speed of 9.6 Gbps. Wi-Fi 6E extends this to the 6 GHz band. It introduces OFDMA and MU-MIMO improvements.

questions.question: Which IPv6 address is the equivalent of the IPv4 loopback address 127.0.0.1?
questions.explanation: The IPv6 loopback address is ::1 (0000:...:0001). FE80::1 is a link-local address. FF02::1 is the all-nodes multicast address. ::FFFF:127.0.0.1 is an IPv4-mapped IPv6 address.

questions.question: Which Ethernet standard uses Cat6a cabling and supports 10 Gbps at distances up to 100 meters?
questions.explanation: 10GBASE-T uses Cat6a (or Cat6 at reduced distance) copper cabling for 10 Gbps at up to 100 meters. 1000BASE-T is 1 Gbps over Cat5e/Cat6. 10GBASE-SR uses multimode fiber. 100GBASE-LR4 uses single-mode fiber.

questions.question: In a star topology, what happens to the rest of the network if the central device fails?
options: Only half the network goes down
The network continues to function normally
A backup path is automatically used
questions.explanation: In a star topology, all devices connect through a central device (switch or hub). If that central device fails, all connected devices lose network connectivity. This is the primary disadvantage of a star topology.

questions.question: What is the default VLAN on a Cisco switch that all ports belong to initially?
questions.explanation: On Cisco switches, VLAN 1 is the default VLAN. All switch ports are members of VLAN 1 by default. VLAN 1 cannot be deleted or renamed. VLANs 1002-1005 are reserved for legacy Token Ring and FDDI.

questions.question: Which IEEE standard defines VLAN tagging on trunk links?
questions.explanation: IEEE 802.1Q defines VLAN tagging by inserting a 4-byte tag into the Ethernet frame header on trunk links. 802.1D is Spanning Tree Protocol. 802.3 defines Ethernet. 802.11 defines wireless LANs.

questions.question: Which Cisco IOS command assigns a switch port to VLAN 20?
questions.explanation: The 'switchport access vlan 20' command assigns the port to VLAN 20 as an access port. 'vlan 20' creates the VLAN in global config. 'switchport trunk allowed vlan 20' restricts trunk traffic to VLAN 20.

questions.question: Which inter-VLAN routing method uses a single physical router interface with subinterfaces?
questions.explanation: Router-on-a-stick uses a single physical interface divided into subinterfaces, each configured with 802.1Q encapsulation for a different VLAN. This is cost-effective but creates a bandwidth bottleneck on the single link.

questions.question: On a router-on-a-stick configuration, which command enables 802.1Q encapsulation for VLAN 10 on subinterface GigabitEthernet0/1.10?
questions.explanation: On a router subinterface, the command 'encapsulation dot1q 10' associates it with VLAN 10 using 802.1Q tagging. The 'switchport trunk encapsulation dot1q' command is used on Layer 2 switches, not routers.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of the Spanning Tree Protocol (STP)?
options: To prevent Layer 2 loops in redundant topologies
To assign IP addresses to switch ports
questions.explanation: STP (IEEE 802.1D) prevents Layer 2 loops by placing redundant ports in a blocking state. Without STP, broadcast storms, MAC table instability, and duplicate frames would occur in networks with redundant paths.

questions.question: In STP, which switch becomes the root bridge?
options: The switch with the highest bridge ID
The switch with the lowest bridge ID
The switch with the most ports
The switch with the highest MAC address
questions.explanation: The root bridge is the switch with the lowest bridge ID, which consists of the priority value (default 32768) plus the MAC address. If priorities are equal, the lowest MAC address wins.

questions.question: What are the STP port states in IEEE 802.1D?
questions.explanation: IEEE 802.1D (classic STP) has five port states: Blocking, Listening, Learning, Forwarding, and Disabled. RSTP (802.1w) simplifies these to three: Discarding, Learning, and Forwarding.

questions.question: How does Rapid Spanning Tree Protocol (RSTP, 802.1w) improve upon classic STP?
options: It uses a different root bridge election process
It converges faster by defining new port roles and active topology negotiation
It eliminates the need for redundant links
questions.explanation: RSTP (802.1w) converges significantly faster than STP (seconds vs. 30-50 seconds) by introducing proposal/agreement handshakes, new port roles (Alternate, Backup), and reducing port states to three (Discarding, Learning, Forwarding).

questions.question: What is the purpose of EtherChannel?
options: To encrypt trunk traffic between switches
To bundle multiple physical links into one logical link
To assign VLANs to switch ports
To prioritize traffic based on QoS markings
questions.explanation: EtherChannel bundles multiple physical interfaces into a single logical link, increasing bandwidth and providing redundancy. If one link fails, traffic continues on the remaining links without STP reconvergence.

questions.question: Which EtherChannel negotiation protocol is an IEEE standard?
questions.explanation: LACP (Link Aggregation Control Protocol, IEEE 802.3ad) is the industry standard for EtherChannel negotiation. PAgP (Port Aggregation Protocol) is Cisco proprietary. DTP negotiates trunks; VTP manages VLANs.

questions.question: When configuring LACP, which mode actively sends LACP packets to form an EtherChannel?
questions.explanation: LACP 'active' mode actively sends LACP negotiation packets. 'Passive' mode only responds to LACP packets. At least one side must be active. 'Desirable' and 'auto' are PAgP modes. 'On' forces the channel without negotiation.

questions.question: In a Cisco wireless architecture, what does a WLC do?
options: Provides DHCP services to wireless clients
Centrally manages and configures lightweight access points
Replaces the need for a router
questions.explanation: A Wireless LAN Controller (WLC) centrally manages lightweight access points (LWAPs), handling configuration, firmware updates, security policies, and RF management. LWAPs rely on the WLC for most intelligence.

questions.question: Which protocol is used for communication between a Cisco WLC and lightweight access points?
questions.explanation: CAPWAP (Control and Provisioning of Wireless Access Points) is the standard protocol for WLC-to-LWAP communication, running on UDP ports 5246 (control) and 5247 (data). LWAPP was the predecessor protocol.

questions.question: Which Cisco AP mode allows the access point to scan all channels for rogue devices and interference without serving clients?
questions.explanation: Monitor mode dedicates the AP to scanning all channels for rogue APs, rogue clients, and RF interference. It does not serve clients. Local mode is the default serving mode. FlexConnect allows local switching at branch offices.

questions.question: What is a native VLAN, and what security risk does a misconfigured native VLAN introduce?
options: The VLAN for management traffic; risk of unauthorized management access
The untagged VLAN on a trunk; risk of VLAN hopping attacks
The VLAN for voice traffic; risk of eavesdropping
The VLAN for guest access; risk of data leakage
questions.explanation: The native VLAN carries untagged traffic on an 802.1Q trunk (default VLAN 1). If native VLANs mismatch between switches or remain default, attackers can craft double-tagged frames to hop into another VLAN (VLAN hopping).

questions.question: A network has three switches. Switch A has priority 24576, Switch B has priority 32768, and Switch C has priority 28672. Which switch becomes the STP root bridge?
options: Cannot be determined without MAC addresses
questions.explanation: The root bridge is the switch with the lowest bridge ID. Since Switch A has the lowest priority (24576), it becomes the root bridge. MAC addresses are only used as a tiebreaker when priorities are equal.

questions.question: Which command configures a Cisco switch port as a trunk?
questions.explanation: The 'switchport mode trunk' command configures a port as a trunk that carries traffic for multiple VLANs. 'switchport access vlan 1' sets an access port. 'switchport nonegotiate' disables DTP negotiation.

questions.question: What happens if one side of an EtherChannel is configured as LACP active and the other side is configured as PAgP desirable?
options: The EtherChannel does not form because LACP and PAgP are incompatible
The channel falls back to static mode
Only one link in the bundle becomes active
questions.explanation: LACP (IEEE) and PAgP (Cisco proprietary) are incompatible protocols. Both sides must use the same protocol (both LACP or both PAgP) or both be set to 'on' (static) for the EtherChannel to form.

questions.question: In Cisco FlexConnect mode, what happens to wireless client traffic when the WLC is unreachable?
options: All wireless clients are disconnected immediately
The AP continues to switch client traffic locally
Traffic is buffered until the WLC reconnects
The AP reboots and rejoins the WLC
questions.explanation: In FlexConnect (formerly H-REAP) mode, the AP can switch client data traffic locally even when the WLC connection is lost. Clients on locally switched WLANs continue to operate. New client authentications may be limited.

questions.question: Which type of switch port carries traffic for only a single VLAN?
questions.explanation: An access port belongs to one VLAN and carries untagged traffic for that VLAN only. Trunk ports carry tagged traffic for multiple VLANs. Routed ports function as Layer 3 interfaces.

questions.question: What is the default STP bridge priority on a Cisco switch?
questions.explanation: The default STP bridge priority on Cisco switches is 32768. Priority values range from 0 to 61440 in increments of 4096. The lower the priority, the more likely the switch becomes root bridge.

questions.question: Which wireless AP mode allows local data switching and central authentication, making it ideal for branch offices?
questions.explanation: FlexConnect mode allows the AP to switch data locally while still authenticating clients centrally through the WLC. This reduces WAN bandwidth usage and is ideal for branch/remote office deployments.

questions.question: A trunk port is configured with 'switchport trunk allowed vlan 10,20,30'. What happens to traffic from VLAN 40?
options: It is tagged and forwarded normally
It is sent as native VLAN traffic
It is dropped by the trunk
It is forwarded to the management VLAN
questions.explanation: When 'switchport trunk allowed vlan' restricts the trunk to specific VLANs, traffic from VLANs not in the list (like VLAN 40) is dropped and not forwarded across the trunk link.

questions.question: Which STP port role receives the best BPDU from the root bridge?
questions.explanation: The root port on each non-root switch is the port with the best (lowest cost) path to the root bridge. Each non-root switch has exactly one root port. Designated ports forward traffic on a segment; alternate ports are RSTP blocking ports.

questions.question: How many physical links can be bundled into a single EtherChannel on Cisco switches?
questions.explanation: Cisco EtherChannel supports bundling up to 8 physical interfaces into a single logical channel. All member interfaces must have matching speed, duplex, VLAN, and trunk settings.

questions.question: Which DTP mode will cause a port to actively try to convert the link to a trunk?
questions.explanation: Dynamic desirable mode actively tries to negotiate a trunk link with the neighbor. Dynamic auto only forms a trunk if the other side is set to trunk or desirable. It is a best practice to disable DTP with 'switchport nonegotiate'.

questions.question: What is the CAPWAP control channel port number, and is it encrypted?
options: UDP 5246, encrypted with DTLS by default
UDP 5247, encrypted with DTLS by default
questions.explanation: CAPWAP uses UDP port 5246 for the control channel, which is encrypted with DTLS (Datagram Transport Layer Security) by default. The data channel uses UDP 5247 and is not encrypted by default.

questions.question: What STP feature allows an access port to immediately transition to the forwarding state, bypassing listening and learning?
questions.explanation: PortFast allows access ports connected to end devices to skip the listening (15s) and learning (15s) states, transitioning directly to forwarding. It should only be enabled on ports connected to hosts, not switches.

questions.question: Which command displays the VLAN assignment for all switch ports?
questions.explanation: The 'show vlan brief' command displays all VLANs and the ports assigned to each VLAN in a concise format. 'show interfaces trunk' shows trunk port information. 'show ip interface brief' shows Layer 3 interface status.

questions.question: Which type of route is manually configured by a network administrator?
questions.explanation: A static route is manually configured by an administrator using the 'ip route' command. Connected routes are automatically added when an interface is configured with an IP address and brought up. Dynamic routes are learned through routing protocols.

questions.question: What is the Cisco IOS command to configure a static route to 10.0.0.0/8 via next-hop 192.168.1.1?
questions.explanation: The Cisco IOS syntax is 'ip route [network] [subnet-mask] [next-hop]'. So 'ip route 10.0.0.0 255.0.0.0 192.168.1.1' creates a static route to 10.0.0.0/8 via 192.168.1.1.

questions.question: Which command creates a default static route (gateway of last resort) on a Cisco router?
questions.explanation: The command 'ip route 0.0.0.0 0.0.0.0 [next-hop]' creates a default route (also called the gateway of last resort). The 0.0.0.0 0.0.0.0 matches all destinations not found in the routing table.

questions.question: Which routing protocol uses the Shortest Path First (SPF) algorithm?
questions.explanation: OSPF (Open Shortest Path First) uses Dijkstra's SPF algorithm to calculate the best path to each destination. RIP uses hop count. EIGRP uses DUAL (Diffusing Update Algorithm). BGP uses path vector.

questions.question: What is the default OSPF cost for a GigabitEthernet interface (1 Gbps)?
questions.explanation: OSPF cost = Reference Bandwidth / Interface Bandwidth. The default reference bandwidth is 100 Mbps. For a 1 Gbps link: 100/1000 = 0.1, which rounds to 1 (minimum). This is why the reference bandwidth should be adjusted for high-speed links.

questions.question: In single-area OSPF, all routers share the same LSDB. What does LSDB stand for?
questions.explanation: LSDB stands for Link-State Database. In single-area OSPF, all routers in the area maintain an identical LSDB containing LSAs (Link-State Advertisements) that describe the topology. Each router runs SPF on this database.

questions.question: Which OSPF router type connects an OSPF area to the backbone area (Area 0)?
questions.explanation: An Area Border Router (ABR) has interfaces in two or more OSPF areas, including Area 0 (backbone). It summarizes routes between areas. An ASBR connects OSPF to external routing domains. Internal routers have all interfaces in one area.

questions.question: What is the administrative distance of OSPF?
questions.explanation: OSPF has an administrative distance of 110. EIGRP internal is 90, RIP is 120, static routes are 1, and directly connected is 0. Lower AD values are preferred when multiple routing sources know a route.

questions.question: If a router has the same destination from a static route (AD 1) and OSPF (AD 110), which is installed in the routing table?
questions.explanation: The route with the lowest administrative distance is preferred. A static route (AD 1) is preferred over OSPF (AD 110). Administrative distance is the trustworthiness of the routing source.

questions.question: What is the administrative distance of a directly connected network?
questions.explanation: Directly connected networks have an administrative distance of 0, the most trusted. Static routes have AD 1, EIGRP internal AD 90, OSPF AD 110, and RIP AD 120.

questions.question: Which command displays the routing table on a Cisco router?
questions.explanation: The 'show ip route' command displays the IPv4 routing table, including connected, static, and dynamically learned routes along with their administrative distances and metrics.

questions.question: In the output of 'show ip route', what does the code 'O' represent?
questions.explanation: In the routing table, 'O' indicates an OSPF-learned route. 'C' is connected, 'S' is static, 'D' is EIGRP, 'R' is RIP, and 'B' is BGP. 'O IA' indicates OSPF inter-area routes.

questions.question: Which first hop redundancy protocol is Cisco proprietary?
questions.explanation: Both HSRP (Hot Standby Router Protocol) and GLBP (Gateway Load Balancing Protocol) are Cisco proprietary. VRRP (Virtual Router Redundancy Protocol) is the IEEE/IETF open standard (RFC 5798).

questions.question: What is the default HSRP priority, and how is the active router elected?
questions.explanation: HSRP default priority is 100 (range 0-255). The router with the highest priority becomes the active router. If priorities are tied, the router with the highest IP address on the HSRP interface wins.

questions.question: Which FHRP protocol provides load balancing by assigning different virtual MAC addresses to hosts?
questions.explanation: GLBP (Gateway Load Balancing Protocol) is unique among FHRPs because it provides both redundancy and load balancing. GLBP assigns different virtual MAC addresses (via AVFs) to clients, distributing traffic across multiple routers.

questions.question: Which OSPF network type uses a Designated Router (DR) and Backup Designated Router (BDR)?
questions.explanation: On broadcast multiaccess networks (e.g., Ethernet), OSPF elects a DR and BDR to reduce OSPF traffic. All other routers (DROthers) form adjacencies only with the DR/BDR. Point-to-point links do not use DR/BDR.

questions.question: What is the OSPF router ID selection order of preference?
options: Lowest IP on any interface, then loopback
Manually configured, then highest loopback IP, then highest physical IP
MAC address of the first interface
questions.explanation: OSPF selects the router ID in this order: (1) manually configured via 'router-id' command, (2) highest IP on a loopback interface, (3) highest IP on an active physical interface. A router restart or 'clear ip ospf process' is needed to apply changes.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of IPv6 Neighbor Discovery Protocol (NDP)?
options: To assign IPv6 addresses via DHCP
To replace ARP and perform address resolution, router discovery, and autoconfiguration
To route IPv6 packets between autonomous systems
questions.explanation: NDP replaces ARP in IPv6 and provides address resolution (Neighbor Solicitation/Advertisement), router discovery (Router Solicitation/Advertisement), duplicate address detection, and SLAAC support using ICMPv6.

questions.question: Which IPv6 address autoconfiguration method uses Router Advertisement messages to form a full IPv6 address?
questions.explanation: SLAAC (Stateless Address Autoconfiguration) allows hosts to create their own IPv6 address using the prefix from Router Advertisement (RA) messages combined with a self-generated interface ID (EUI-64 or random). No DHCP server is needed.

questions.question: Which command enables OSPF on a Cisco router and assigns it process ID 1?
questions.explanation: The 'router ospf 1' command enters OSPF router configuration mode with process ID 1. The process ID is locally significant and does not need to match between OSPF neighbors. It is followed by 'network' statements.

questions.question: Two OSPF routers are not forming an adjacency. Which parameter mismatch would prevent adjacency formation?
questions.explanation: OSPF neighbors must agree on hello/dead timers, area ID, subnet, authentication, and network type. Mismatched hello/dead timers prevent adjacency. Process IDs and hostnames are locally significant. Different router IDs are required.

questions.question: A floating static route has an administrative distance of 95. When will this route be used?
options: It is always used because it has a lower AD than OSPF
It is used only when the primary EIGRP route (AD 90) is unavailable
It is never used because static routes always have AD 1
It is used as a load-balancing route alongside EIGRP
questions.explanation: A floating static route has a manually configured higher AD to serve as a backup. With AD 95, it is not installed when EIGRP (AD 90) has the route. If the EIGRP route disappears, the floating static route (AD 95) is installed as a backup.

questions.question: A router has these routes: 10.1.0.0/16 via OSPF and 10.1.1.0/24 via static. A packet is destined for 10.1.1.50. Which route is used?
options: OSPF route (10.1.0.0/16) because it was learned first
Static route (10.1.1.0/24) because it has the longest prefix match
Both routes are used for load balancing
The packet is dropped because there is ambiguity
questions.explanation: Routers use longest prefix match for forwarding decisions. The /24 route is more specific than the /16 route for destination 10.1.1.50, so the static route (10.1.1.0/24) is used regardless of administrative distance.

questions.question: What type of routing protocol is EIGRP?
questions.explanation: EIGRP is classified as an advanced distance-vector (or hybrid) routing protocol. It uses features from both distance-vector (sending updates to neighbors) and link-state (maintaining a topology table) protocols.

questions.question: What type of IPv6 address begins with FE80?
questions.explanation: IPv6 link-local addresses begin with FE80::/10. They are automatically assigned to every IPv6-enabled interface and are used for communication on the local link only (not routable). They are required for IPv6 routing protocols.

questions.question: In OSPF, what are the default hello and dead timer intervals on a broadcast network?
questions.explanation: On broadcast and point-to-point networks, OSPF uses a 10-second hello timer and a 40-second dead timer (4x hello). On NBMA networks, the defaults are 30 seconds and 120 seconds respectively.

questions.question: Which virtual IP address does HSRP version 1 use by default for group 1?
options: The virtual IP must be configured manually
questions.explanation: HSRP does not assign a default virtual IP address; it must be manually configured using the 'standby [group] ip [virtual-ip]' command. HSRP v1 uses multicast 224.0.0.2, and HSRP v2 uses 224.0.0.102.

questions.question: Which IPv6 static route command configures a default route via next-hop FE80::1 on interface GigabitEthernet0/0?
questions.explanation: The command 'ipv6 route ::/0 GigabitEthernet0/0 FE80::1' creates a default IPv6 route. When using a link-local next-hop address, the exit interface must be specified because link-local addresses are not unique across interfaces.

questions.question: Which OSPF packet type is used to exchange link-state database entries between routers?
questions.explanation: Link-State Update (LSU) packets carry LSAs between OSPF routers. DBD packets summarize the LSDB during initial exchange. LSR packets request specific LSAs. Hello packets discover and maintain neighbors.

questions.question: What is the administrative distance of EIGRP external routes?
questions.explanation: EIGRP external routes (redistributed into EIGRP from another source) have an AD of 170. EIGRP internal routes have AD 90, EIGRP summary routes have AD 5. This higher AD for external routes reflects lower trust.

questions.question: Which method does EUI-64 use to generate the interface ID portion of an IPv6 address?
options: Uses the first 64 bits of the IPv6 prefix
Inserts FFFE in the middle of the 48-bit MAC address and flips the 7th bit
Uses the serial number of the network interface
questions.explanation: EUI-64 takes the 48-bit MAC address, splits it into two halves, inserts FFFE in the middle to create a 64-bit identifier, and inverts the 7th bit (Universal/Local bit). This forms the interface ID of the IPv6 address.

questions.question: What does 'longest prefix match' mean in the context of IP routing?
options: The route with the highest administrative distance is preferred
The route with the most specific (longest) subnet mask matching the destination is used
The route with the fewest hops is preferred
The route that has been in the table longest is preferred
questions.explanation: Longest prefix match means the router selects the route with the most specific subnet mask that matches the destination IP. A /24 route is preferred over a /16 route for the same destination. This is the fundamental forwarding decision.

questions.question: What problem do First Hop Redundancy Protocols solve?
options: IP address exhaustion on the LAN
Single point of failure for the default gateway
questions.explanation: FHRPs (HSRP, VRRP, GLBP) solve the single point of failure problem for the default gateway. If a router fails, another router in the FHRP group takes over the virtual IP address, providing seamless failover for hosts.

questions.question: Which OSPF neighbor state indicates that routers have fully synchronized their link-state databases?
questions.explanation: The Full state means OSPF neighbors have fully synchronized their LSDBs. The progression is: Down > Init > 2-Way > ExStart > Exchange > Loading > Full. DR/BDR elections happen at the 2-Way state.

questions.question: Which routing table entry represents a summary route for 192.168.0.0 to 192.168.3.0?
questions.explanation: The range 192.168.0.0 through 192.168.3.255 covers 4 Class C networks (0, 1, 2, 3). A /22 mask (255.255.252.0) provides exactly this range. /24 covers only .0.0, /23 covers only .0.0-.1.0, and /16 is too broad.

questions.question: What metric does EIGRP use by default to calculate the best path?
questions.explanation: By default, EIGRP uses bandwidth and delay to calculate its composite metric. Although EIGRP can also factor in reliability and load (K values), by default K1 (bandwidth) and K3 (delay) are set to 1, while K2, K4, and K5 are 0.

questions.question: Which OSPFv3 feature differentiates it from OSPFv2?
options: OSPFv3 uses TCP instead of IP protocol 89
OSPFv3 does not elect a DR/BDR
questions.explanation: OSPFv3 is the version of OSPF designed for IPv6 routing, defined in RFC 5340. It still uses areas, DR/BDR elections, and runs over IP protocol 89. OSPFv3 uses link-local addresses for neighbor communication.

questions.question: A packet arrives at a router with no matching route in the routing table. What happens if there is no default route configured?
options: The router broadcasts the packet out all interfaces
The router sends the packet back to the source
The router drops the packet and may send an ICMP Destination Unreachable message
The router buffers the packet indefinitely
questions.explanation: If no matching route exists and no default route is configured, the router drops the packet. It typically sends an ICMP Destination Unreachable (Network Unreachable) message back to the source to indicate the failure.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a DHCP relay agent?
options: To forward DHCP broadcast requests to a DHCP server on a different subnet
questions.explanation: A DHCP relay agent (configured with 'ip helper-address') forwards DHCP broadcast requests from clients to a DHCP server located on a different subnet. Without a relay, DHCP broadcasts cannot cross router boundaries.

questions.question: Which Cisco IOS command configures a router interface to relay DHCP requests to server 10.1.1.100?
questions.explanation: The 'ip helper-address 10.1.1.100' command, configured on the interface facing the client subnet, forwards UDP broadcasts (including DHCP) to the specified server. It also forwards TFTP, DNS, TACACS, and other UDP services by default.

questions.question: What type of DNS record maps a hostname to an IPv4 address?
questions.explanation: An A (Address) record maps a hostname to an IPv4 address. AAAA records map to IPv6 addresses. CNAME records create aliases. MX records specify mail servers for a domain.

questions.question: What does NAT stand for, and what is its primary purpose?
options: Network Address Translation; translates private IP addresses to public IP addresses
Network Access Technology; controls network access
Network Authentication Token; verifies user identity
questions.explanation: NAT (Network Address Translation) translates private (RFC 1918) IP addresses to public IP addresses, allowing internal hosts to access the internet. It also helps conserve the limited IPv4 address space.

questions.question: What is the difference between NAT and PAT?
options: NAT translates MAC addresses; PAT translates IP addresses
NAT provides one-to-one translation; PAT maps multiple private IPs to one public IP using port numbers
NAT is for IPv6; PAT is for IPv4
There is no difference; they are the same
questions.explanation: Static NAT provides one-to-one IP translation. PAT (Port Address Translation), also called NAT overload, maps multiple internal private IP addresses to a single public IP address by using unique source port numbers to distinguish sessions.

questions.question: What protocol synchronizes clocks across network devices?
questions.explanation: NTP (Network Time Protocol) synchronizes clocks across network devices using UDP port 123. Accurate time is critical for log correlation, certificate validation, and troubleshooting. NTP can achieve millisecond accuracy.

questions.question: Which version of SNMP provides both encryption and authentication?
questions.explanation: SNMPv3 is the only version that provides both authentication (SHA/MD5) and encryption (AES/DES) through its security model. SNMPv1 and SNMPv2c use plaintext community strings with no encryption.

questions.question: What syslog severity level represents an emergency condition?
questions.explanation: Syslog severity level 0 is Emergency (system is unusable). The levels are: 0-Emergency, 1-Alert, 2-Critical, 3-Error, 4-Warning, 5-Notification, 6-Informational, 7-Debugging. Lower numbers are more severe.

questions.question: Which QoS mechanism classifies and marks packets at the network edge?
questions.explanation: Classification and marking identify traffic types and mark them with appropriate values (DSCP, CoS) at the network edge. Queuing manages how marked packets are scheduled. Policing and shaping control traffic rates.

questions.question: What is the DSCP value for Expedited Forwarding (EF), commonly used for voice traffic?
questions.explanation: Expedited Forwarding (EF) uses DSCP 46 and is used for delay-sensitive traffic like voice. DSCP 0 is best effort. AF classes use values like 26 (AF31). DSCP 48 is CS6, used for network control.

questions.question: Which protocol provides secure remote CLI access to network devices?
questions.explanation: SSH (Secure Shell) provides encrypted remote CLI access using TCP port 22. Telnet (port 23) sends data in cleartext and should not be used. HTTP (port 80) is for web access. SNMP is for network monitoring.

questions.question: In Cisco NAT terminology, what is the 'inside global' address?
options: The private IP address assigned to an internal host
The public IP address that represents an internal host to the outside world
The IP address of the external server
The private IP of the NAT router
questions.explanation: Inside global is the public IP address that represents an internal host on the external network. Inside local is the private IP. Outside global is the real IP of the external host. Outside local is how the external host appears internally.

questions.question: What is DHCP snooping and what does it protect against?
options: A routing protocol feature that validates DHCP configurations
A Layer 2 security feature that filters untrusted DHCP messages to prevent rogue DHCP servers
An encryption method for DHCP traffic
questions.explanation: DHCP snooping is a Layer 2 security feature that validates DHCP messages. It classifies ports as trusted (toward legitimate DHCP server) or untrusted (toward clients). It blocks DHCP server messages on untrusted ports, preventing rogue DHCP attacks.

questions.question: Which SNMPv3 security level provides authentication but no encryption?
questions.explanation: SNMPv3 has three security levels: noAuthNoPriv (username only), authNoPriv (authentication with MD5/SHA but no encryption), and authPriv (authentication plus encryption with DES/AES). authNoPriv ensures message integrity without confidentiality.

questions.question: Which syslog severity level represents a Warning?
questions.explanation: Syslog level 4 is Warning. The mnemonic 'Every Alley Cat Eats Watery Noodle In December' helps remember: 0-Emergency, 1-Alert, 2-Critical, 3-Error, 4-Warning, 5-Notification, 6-Informational, 7-Debug.

questions.question: What do the three components of the CIA triad stand for?
questions.explanation: The CIA triad stands for Confidentiality (data is accessible only to authorized users), Integrity (data is accurate and unaltered), and Availability (systems and data are accessible when needed). It is the foundation of information security.

questions.question: What does AAA stand for in network security?
questions.explanation: AAA stands for Authentication (verifying identity), Authorization (determining access rights), and Accounting (tracking user activities). RADIUS and TACACS+ are common AAA protocols used in network environments.

questions.question: Which Cisco feature limits the number of MAC addresses learned on a switch port?
questions.explanation: Port security limits the number of MAC addresses that can be learned on a switch port. If the limit is exceeded, the port can shut down, restrict, or protect. This helps prevent MAC flooding attacks.

questions.question: What are the three violation modes for Cisco port security?
questions.explanation: Port security has three violation modes: Protect (drops violating traffic silently), Restrict (drops traffic and sends SNMP/syslog alerts), and Shutdown (default; disables the port in err-disabled state and sends an alert).

questions.question: What does Dynamic ARP Inspection (DAI) protect against?
questions.explanation: DAI validates ARP packets against the DHCP snooping binding table. It prevents ARP spoofing/poisoning attacks where a malicious host sends fake ARP replies to redirect traffic through itself (man-in-the-middle).

questions.question: Which type of ACL filters traffic based only on the source IP address?
questions.explanation: Standard ACLs (numbered 1-99, 1300-1999) filter traffic based only on the source IP address. Extended ACLs filter on source/destination IP, protocol, and port numbers. Standard ACLs should be placed close to the destination.

questions.question: What is the numbered range for standard IP ACLs on Cisco devices?
questions.explanation: Standard IP ACLs use numbers 1-99 and the expanded range 1300-1999. Extended ACLs use 100-199 and 2000-2699. Named ACLs use descriptive names instead of numbers.

questions.question: Where should an extended ACL be placed for optimal efficiency?
options: On every router in the path
questions.explanation: Extended ACLs should be placed close to the source of traffic to prevent unwanted packets from traversing the network unnecessarily. Standard ACLs should be placed close to the destination because they only filter on source IP.

questions.question: Which wireless security protocol uses AES encryption and is currently recommended?
questions.explanation: WPA2 uses AES-CCMP encryption and is the minimum recommended wireless security standard. WEP uses RC4 (broken). WPA uses TKIP (deprecated). WPA3 offers even stronger security with SAE authentication.

questions.question: What improvement does WPA3 provide over WPA2 for personal networks?
options: Replaces PSK with Simultaneous Authentication of Equals (SAE)
questions.explanation: WPA3 Personal replaces the PSK (Pre-Shared Key) handshake with SAE (Simultaneous Authentication of Equals), which provides protection against offline dictionary attacks and forward secrecy, even if the password is later compromised.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a site-to-site VPN?
options: To provide remote access for individual users
To create an encrypted tunnel between two network locations over the internet
To load balance traffic across multiple ISPs
questions.explanation: A site-to-site VPN creates a permanent encrypted tunnel between two network locations (e.g., headquarters and branch office) over a public network. Remote-access VPNs serve individual users connecting to the corporate network.

questions.question: What protocol does 802.1X use for network access control?
options: RADIUS or TACACS+ as the authentication server
questions.explanation: 802.1X is a port-based network access control standard that uses EAP (Extensible Authentication Protocol) and typically RADIUS as the backend authentication server. It has three components: supplicant, authenticator, and authentication server.

questions.question: Which command configures port security with a maximum of 2 MAC addresses and shutdown violation mode?
options: switchport port-security / switchport port-security maximum 2 / switchport port-security violation shutdown
questions.explanation: Port security requires multiple commands: 'switchport port-security' enables it, 'switchport port-security maximum 2' sets the MAC limit, and 'switchport port-security violation shutdown' sets the action. The port must first be set to access or trunk mode.

questions.question: What is the implicit rule at the end of every Cisco ACL?
questions.explanation: Every Cisco ACL has an implicit 'deny any' (deny all) at the end. Any traffic not explicitly matched by a permit statement is dropped. This is why at least one permit statement is needed for an ACL to pass any traffic.

questions.question: What is the difference between a stateful and stateless firewall?
options: Stateful firewalls are hardware; stateless are software
Stateful firewalls track connection states; stateless firewalls evaluate each packet independently
Stateless firewalls are more secure than stateful
questions.explanation: Stateful firewalls maintain a state table tracking active connections, allowing return traffic automatically. Stateless firewalls (like basic ACLs) evaluate each packet independently without connection context, requiring explicit rules for return traffic.

questions.question: Which AAA protocol separates authentication, authorization, and accounting, and uses TCP port 49?
questions.explanation: TACACS+ (Cisco) separates AAA functions, uses TCP port 49, and encrypts the entire packet body. RADIUS combines authentication and authorization, uses UDP (1812/1813 or 1645/1646), and only encrypts the password.

questions.question: Which attack is mitigated by configuring DHCP snooping with rate limiting on untrusted ports?
questions.explanation: DHCP starvation attacks flood the DHCP server with fake requests to exhaust the IP address pool. DHCP snooping with rate limiting on untrusted ports restricts the number of DHCP messages per second, mitigating this attack.

questions.question: In 802.1X, what role does the switch play?
questions.explanation: In 802.1X, the switch acts as the authenticator, controlling physical access to the network. The client device is the supplicant, and the RADIUS server is the authentication server. The switch forwards credentials between them.

questions.question: Which VPN protocol suite provides confidentiality, integrity, and authentication at the network layer?
questions.explanation: IPsec operates at the Network layer (Layer 3) and provides confidentiality (ESP encryption), integrity (HMAC), and authentication (IKE). SSL/TLS operates at the Session/Transport layer. L2TP alone provides no encryption; it is often paired with IPsec.

questions.question: Which extended ACL statement permits HTTP traffic from 192.168.1.0/24 to any destination?
questions.explanation: The correct syntax uses 'permit tcp [source] [wildcard] any eq 80'. Cisco ACLs use wildcard masks (0.0.0.255), not subnet masks. HTTP uses TCP port 80. The keyword 'allow' is not valid in Cisco ACLs.

questions.question: Which attack exploits WPA2-Personal's 4-way handshake to perform offline password cracking?
options: Capturing the handshake and running a dictionary attack
questions.explanation: An attacker can capture the WPA2 4-way handshake (by deauthenticating a client) and then perform offline dictionary/brute-force attacks against the PSK. WPA3-SAE mitigates this by preventing offline attacks. KRACK is a different protocol-level vulnerability.

questions.question: Which type of firewall inspects traffic at the application layer and can filter based on content?
questions.explanation: Next-generation firewalls (NGFWs) inspect traffic at the application layer, providing deep packet inspection, intrusion prevention, URL filtering, and content analysis beyond traditional stateful inspection.

questions.question: What does REST stand for in the context of APIs?
questions.explanation: REST (Representational State Transfer) is an architectural style for APIs that uses standard HTTP methods (GET, POST, PUT, DELETE) and typically returns data in JSON or XML format. RESTful APIs are stateless and resource-based.

questions.question: Which HTTP method is used to retrieve data from a REST API?
questions.explanation: The HTTP GET method retrieves (reads) data from a REST API without modifying it. POST creates new resources, PUT updates existing resources, and DELETE removes resources. These map to CRUD operations.

questions.question: Which data format uses curly braces and key-value pairs, commonly used in REST APIs?
questions.explanation: JSON (JavaScript Object Notation) uses curly braces for objects and key-value pairs (e.g., {"name": "Router1"}). It is lightweight and widely used in REST APIs. XML uses tags. YAML uses indentation.

questions.question: Which data serialization format uses opening and closing tags similar to HTML?
questions.explanation: XML (Extensible Markup Language) uses opening and closing tags (e.g., <name>Router1</name>). It is more verbose than JSON but supports schemas and namespaces. NETCONF uses XML for network device configuration.

questions.question: What is Cisco DNA Center?
options: A controller-based network management platform for intent-based networking
questions.explanation: Cisco DNA (Digital Network Architecture) Center is a centralized management platform for intent-based networking. It provides automation, assurance, policy-based segmentation, and analytics for campus and branch networks.

questions.question: What does SDN stand for?
questions.explanation: SDN (Software Defined Networking) separates the control plane from the data plane, centralizing network intelligence in a controller. This enables programmable, agile, and dynamic network management through APIs.

questions.question: In SDN architecture, which plane is responsible for making forwarding decisions?
questions.explanation: In SDN, the control plane (centralized in the SDN controller) makes forwarding decisions and programs the data plane. The data plane forwards packets based on controller instructions. The management plane handles device configuration.

questions.question: Which configuration management tool uses agentless, SSH-based automation and YAML playbooks?
questions.explanation: Ansible is agentless (uses SSH/NETCONF), uses YAML-based playbooks for configuration, and is push-based. Puppet uses a pull-based agent model with its own DSL. Chef uses Ruby-based recipes and a pull model.

questions.question: Which configuration management tool uses a pull-based model with agents and its own declarative language?
questions.explanation: Puppet uses a pull-based model where agents on managed nodes periodically pull configurations from a Puppet master. It uses its own declarative DSL. Ansible is push-based and agentless. Terraform is for infrastructure provisioning.

questions.question: What is Infrastructure as Code (IaC)?
options: Managing and provisioning infrastructure through machine-readable definition files
Using CLI commands to configure devices manually
questions.explanation: Infrastructure as Code (IaC) manages infrastructure through version-controlled definition files rather than manual processes. Tools like Terraform and Ansible automate provisioning. IaC enables consistency, repeatability, and version control.

questions.question: Which interface does an SDN controller use to communicate with network devices in the data plane?
questions.explanation: Southbound interfaces/APIs (e.g., OpenFlow, NETCONF, RESTCONF) communicate between the SDN controller and network devices (data plane). Northbound APIs communicate between the controller and applications/management systems.

questions.question: A REST API returns HTTP status code 201. What does this indicate?
options: No Content - Request succeeded but no body returned
questions.explanation: HTTP 201 (Created) indicates a new resource was successfully created, typically in response to a POST request. 200 is OK (general success), 204 is No Content, and 202 is Accepted (asynchronous processing).

questions.question: Which Cisco DNA Center feature automatically maps the network topology and monitors health?
questions.explanation: Cisco DNA Center Assurance provides network health monitoring, automated topology mapping, issue detection, and guided remediation. Design handles network hierarchy; Policy manages access policies; SD-Access provides fabric automation.

questions.question: Which Chef component contains the desired state configuration code written in Ruby?
questions.explanation: Chef uses recipes (written in Ruby DSL) to define the desired state of resources. Recipes are grouped into cookbooks. Ansible uses playbooks (YAML). Puppet uses manifests (.pp files). Chef is agent-based and pull-based.

questions.question: What is a key benefit of controller-based networking compared to traditional networking?
options: It eliminates the need for physical network devices
It provides centralized management, programmability, and consistent policy enforcement
It only works with wireless networks
questions.explanation: Controller-based networking centralizes management and intelligence in a controller, enabling programmability through APIs, consistent policy enforcement across all devices, automation of repetitive tasks, and simplified network-wide changes.
